results.title: Brian Wilson : I wasn't made for these times
results.creator_credit: Don Was, Larry Shapiro, Ken Kushnick, David Passick, Cro-Magnon Films and Palomar Pictures
results.brief_description: Even if you’re not a fan of the Beach Boys, “I Wasn’t Made for These Times” is a fascinating documentary for anyone interested in popular music and songwriting. Filmed in black and white, the film focuses on the life of Brian Wilson and on his contributions as a composer rather than on the turbulent history of the Beach Boys. Intercutting present day footage of Wilson performing in the studio with interviews with his family and himself, Brian Wilson’s life makes compelling viewing. Interviews with musicians such as Tom Petty, Lindsay Buckingham, Linda Ronsdtadt, John Cale, David Crosby and Graham Nash demonstrate the far reaching influence that Brian Wilson had on rock music.

results.title: Brett Whiteley: Alchemy
results.brief_description: A study of the work, philosophy and artistic process of renowned Australian painter, Brett Whiteley, as he prepares for and then exhibits the extensive panel work, “Alchemy”. The program is also integrated with a discussion of the history and mythology of alchemy in the ancient world and of the practices and beliefs of alchemists which weaves, in an explanatory and complementary way, through the coverage of Whiteley as he paints and discusses his work. Whiteley’s sense of producing different languages in painting, of shifting away from Australian naturalism to seek a balance between the natural and the surreal, is evoked insightfully in the program through the extensive interviews and commentary from Whiteley himself, the view of the artist at work in his studio, and through the thread of the study of alchemy. Along with Whiteley’s comments on his personal philosophies, the focus of the discussion delves into his fascinations and experiences, expressed through the form of his paintings, in terms of the alchemist notion of transmutation, and the ideal of a journey towards bursting through the boundary to dreams. This is exemplified in the work “Alchemy”, where the mind on its meanders, an order lost in detail and an eye to the spiritual is presented in the form of a paneled mural. The program contains footage of the opening of the exhibition of this work with its reception analysed through interviews and sound bytes of Whiteley’s colleagues, friends and family, art critics and curators, providing a close to this meditative outline of Brett Whiteley’s artistic process from original concept to exhibition.

results.title: Breeding for quality
results.creator_credit: Western Australian Government Film Unit and Norman A. Uren
results.brief_description: England, Denmark, New Zealand and America are the major dairying countries of the world which use artificial insemination. In order to improve the dairy herds in Western Australia the government has set up a research station which supplies commercial herds with semen from top-quality bulls. Records show that artificial insemination has proved its worth to the dairy farmer in increased production, better quality milk and healthier herds.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Western Australian Government Film Unit and Norman A. Uren

results.title: Breathless = A bout de souffle [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Georges de Beauregard, Societe Nouvelle de Cinematographie, Productions Georges de Beauregard, Imperia and Jean-Luc Godard
results.brief_description: When the “young Turks” from the journal Cahiers du Cinema began making films in the late fifties, they revolutionised cinema by celebrating the look and attitudes of American pop-culture (B-movies, rock and roll) while infusing their own films with the uncertainties of a then distinctly European intellectual scrutiny. In “Breathless” a young hood kills a cop and goes on the run in Paris, hiding at his girlfriend’s flat until she betrays him. That’s life. Kiss-kiss, bang-bang. Playful, cool, name-dropping and audacious the film is true to its title, furiously exploring the possibilities of cinema while acknowledging its aesthetic debt to the low-budget films of Hollywood’s B-directors. Godard’s film remains the most influential of the French New Wave, and as the decade was to progress, Vietnam, Algiers and Maoism were to demand of him a more intellectually dense cinema. But in “Breathless” he is still the cheeky precocious brat, thumbing his nose at the world and inventing a new kind of film. From an original treatment by Francois Trauffaut, and with Claude Charbrol as artist and technical adviser. With Jean-Paul Belmondo and Jean Seberg.

results.title: Breathless
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”.
This Four Corners episode considers the disturbing increase of asthma in Australia. It is estimated that more than one million Australians suffer from the disease. “Breathless” contains interviews with doctors and specialists working on the frontline offering a timely reminder that we are no closer to solving the mystery of this illness, or preventing the many deaths that are caused by it.

results.title: Breathing for others
results.creator_credit: Guy Fergusson and Stewart Hardy Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Emergency Resuscitation”.
Demonstrates the exhaled air method to save life in cases of asphyxia, drowning, gassing, electric shock and suffocation.
